title: Will the Dakota Access Pipeline begin transporting oil before January 2018?
preds: News reports; oil now "flowing through" DAPL: http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/01/us/dakota-access-pipeline-oil-flowing/ http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/335898-dakota-access-pipeline-now-in-service
@JMR2017 has quoted The Hill, it has also been reported on CNN that the pipeline is officially commercial operational: http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/01/us/dakota-access-pipeline-oil-flowing/

https://origin-nyi.thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/335898-dakota-access-pipeline-now-in-service The controversial Dakota Access pipeline has started carrying oil between North Dakota and Illinois, its owner said Thursday. The successful completion of construction and testing opens up a new route for up to 570,000 barrels of oil daily to be carried from major drilling areas in the Bakken oil formation to a major pipeline hub, where it can be carried to refiners or exporters on the Gulf Coast. At 1,172 miles long and 30 inches in diameter, Dakota Access cost $3.8 billion to build, Energy Transfer Partners said. Together with the Illinois-to-Texas Energy Transfer Crude Oil Pipeline, it has 520,000 barrels per day of commitments from shippers, leaving room for another 50,000 barrels.
Appears they are on the precipice of starting to transport crude oil.
Trump and Koch want it. And if they can get it to stop leaking.

FWIW, the following 5/15/17 news report states "...DAPL begins interstate service, pumping crude oil from the Bakken to Illinois." http://www.kfyrtv.com/content/news/Dakota-Access-Pipeline-begins-pumping-crude-oil-from-Bakken-to-Illinois-422384134.html
Unless there is a major spill between oil loading this weekend and the June 1 operational date, combined with a negative court decision......

Dakota Access Pipeline, not yet operational, has already started to spill oil (84 gallons and fully contained)
http://arcgis.sd.gov/server/denr/spillsviewer/.  Enter "Dakota access pipeline" in the name/responsible party field. Pipeline will load oils this weekend and is expected to be fully operational on June 1st.
https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/the-dakota-access-pipeline-is-already-leaking
A lack of will on the part of the legislature and courts will allow the pipeline to become operational even as environmental and social impacts remain.
Barring a domestic act of violence against the pipeline, there doesn't seem to be anything holding it back.

The current US administration is so pro fossil fuels, including our current presidents investment in this particular pipeline, that this will go through.  Beneficial or not to the American people, they will see this through and flag it as success.

The pipeline has been completed, the national agencies that govern the pipeline are headed by a pro oil administration, oil prices are not likely to fall substantially but pose the biggest risk as to why the pipeline would not be put into production. Infrastructure that is completed is usually used.

The company is now saying the pipeline "should be completed by June 1, when the 1,170-mile pipeline is due to enter into service." http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/332810-dakota-access-pipeline-leaks-84-gallons-of-oil-in-sd
The Pipeline is functional and the current Presidential administration will hasten the movement of oil through the pipeline.
Since March 23rd everyone has been saying "any day now".  "Any day now" has been described as "in May", possibly May 14th.

The remaining lawsuit of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe vs. US Army Corps of Engineers doesn't look as though it will stop the pipeline.
"The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe has been pushing for partial summary judgement on claims that the Corps violated NEPA, the Clean Water Act and its duties under tribal treaties by granting the easement and terminating the environmental review". 
The Corps has asked the court for "partial summary judgement in it's favour, saying the tribe 'disagrees with the Corps judgement call regarding how to analyse and discuss risk of an oil spill...the tribe fundamentally has not shown that the risk was 'ignored' or that the Corps has otherwise failed to consider the potential impacts as required by NEPA. Nor has the tribe shown that the Corps violated a substantive trust duty, violated the Clean Water Act or reversed itself without a detailed explanation of any changed circumstances."
https://www.law360.com/articles/911420/dakota-access-mostly-loses-bid-to-shield-suit-documents
Oil money goes farther that Occupy movements or protests.

DAPL is in the final phase; pre-commissioning which involves a series of tests in preparing the pipeline for operation. This involves: filling, cleaning and gauging, hydrotesting, dewatering and drying. (http://www.ppsa-online.com/papers/2005-Aberdeen-2-Russell.pdf)  The Keystone Gulf Coast pipeline (measures 485 miles) was commissioned January 22nd 2014, began line fill operations in December 2013 and were concluded January 21st 2014. (https://www.desmogblog.com/sites/beta.desmogblog.com/files/Final%20report%20of%20Gulf%20Coast%20pipeline.pdf). The Dakota Access Pipeline is 1,172 miles in length (https://daplpipelinefacts.com/about-the-dakota-access-pipeline/) - provided they pass all the safety requirements in the pre-commissioning phase, the pipeline will be able to transport oil by the end of May, if not April, dependent on how long it takes for a pipeline of this size for line fill to be completed.  Can’t see the religious argument from the Standing Rock and Cheyenne River Tribes winning in court as the pipeline is built under the lake, therefore it isn't contaminating the water.

According to this, the pipeline already has oil in it, it just may not be flowing:
“Oil has been placed in the Dakota Access Pipeline underneath Lake Oahe,” Energy Transfer Partners said in a court filing in Washington, DC on March 27. “Dakota Access is currently commissioning the full pipeline and is preparing to place the pipeline into service.” https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/united-states-oil-begins-flow-through-dakota-access-pipeline
The pipeline's opponents have all been solidly BTFO for months and as said elsewhere the pipeline will be operational very soon
The opponents still have a few legal arguments - one on religious grounds and one that the permit shouldn't have been issued in the first place. Those seem very unlikely to prevail.
3/31/17: As noted, pipeline reportedly (planned) to be fully operational in about three weeks. http://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article141212643.html

North Dakota oil production will get a shot in the arm next month as a pipeline comes online despite opposition by environmental groups and Native Americans, allowing the energy industry to save at least $540 million in annual shipping costs.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-north-dakota-pipeline-production-idUSKBN1710F1?il=0
Company says pipeline will be in service 3 weeks from now. http://www.businessinsider.com/ap-what-completed-dakota-access-pipeline-means-for-key-players-2017-3

Oil in the pipeline (according to ETP)
ETP claims that oil will be flowing within a few weeks (3/27/2017)
Why not 100%?
Vandalism of pipeline
Unresolved legal case with Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe

http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/dakota-pipeline-protests/dakota-access-pipeline-now-has-oil-beneath-missouri-river-company-n739296
Pipeline fill has started, like other forecasters have said - oil will be transported soon. http://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Dakota-Access-Pipeline-Loaded-And-Ready-For-Business.html
The pipeline is expected to be completed shortly and oil will begin flowing shortly.

Oil is now in the pipeline, so we're closer to 100 than my previous 99% forecast. (Oil needs to be in the pipeline before there's actual transport of oil happening, so there's a tiny chance now that sabotage could stop this, but it's <0.5%)
3/27/17: Oil in pipeline (reportedly). Not quite yet in service (reportedly): http://time.com/4714686/dakota-access-pipeline-oil-missouri-river/ https://twitter.com/AP/status/846508300023857153
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

construction projects ready for use dates  are tricky to forecast, specially when it is in the area of political swamps however the likelyhood has now greatly improved with the current administration.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-pipeline-keystone-transcanada-idUSKBN16V1CN
https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-comments-keystone-xl-presidential-permit
Still not a gimme, even if M. Petits-Doigts calls the governor of Nebraska, who claims to be happy about all this and confident that the PSC will do a good job of deciding.  The governor has no special control over the independent five-member PSC; it is not clear whether the Prez just doesn't know this, or has been advised by his son-in-law or daughter that it would put the PSC members in an odd ethical position if the Prez calls them to intervene.  My money's on the former, ethics never having loomed large in the family legend. And as long as there are lawyers, almost anything can be held up almost forever.  Still, more likely than not that something will happen this calendar year.  Staying high until I see more on the lawsuits.

Oil is expected to flow soon.  However, a US District Court for the District of Columbia has yet to rule on the SRST and the Cheyenne River Sioux tribes' claims that the USACE violated federal laws in approving the pipeline.  That ruling is expected within the next several weeks.  
http://www.hcn.org/articles/oil-expected-to-flow-through-dakota-access-pipeline-this-week It's down to the wire.  So, which will it be? Also, consider this: Dakota Access LLC filed a heavily redacted report with a D.C. federal court Monday about the progress of its nearly completed pipeline on federal land in North Dakota, saying most of the document had to be filed under seal because of “recent coordinated physical attacks along the pipeline" threatening “life, physical safety, and the environment."
https://www.law360.com/cases/579927ecc7d4c3334f000001

Federal appeal court denied legal challenge by the tribes to halt oil transfer over this weekend. Oil may begin flowing as early as today. http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/dakota-pipeline-protests/appeals-court-refuses-stop-oil-dakota-access-pipeline-n735336
Wasn't ever gonna be stopped. Flint still ain't got clean water lmao.

Article on Platts stating that the Dakota Access Pipeline will likely start transporting oil next week.
 http://blogs.platts.com/2017/03/16/dakota-access-pipeline-bakken-crude-oil/

Quick post-mortum. I don't think I gave the Trump administration enough credit to getting this through in the beginning, I did not fully take political considerations into account either, that should've drastically raised my base rate to start. I spent too much time anchoring around that 40% I feel a lot of hindsight bias as I'm looking over my prior comments and now saying, "you read too much into that" or didn't weigh other signals enough like the Governors input.
Up 2 to 100 on the @jayb and @Khalid links.

As noted: "A federal judge declined Tuesday to temporarily stop construction of the final section of the disputed Dakota Access pipeline, clearing the way for oil to flow as soon as next week.." http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-dakota-pipeline-judge-ruling-20170307-story.html

Judge Boasberg has again declined to temporarily stop construction of DAPL - saying that the tribes "had not raised the religious argument in a timely fashion". The Judge also said that he would likely allow the tribes to raise the religious argument again, but it would not likely succeed. (https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/07/dakota-access-pipeline-court-battle-standing-rock-oil)
This is at least the third time that Judge Boasberg has "denied a bid to block pipeline project progress" (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-07/dakota-access-triumphs-over-tribe-s-challenge-to-pipeline). 
"Both tribes also have asked Boasberg to overturn the federal permission for the Lake Oahe crossing and to bar the corps from granting permission in the future. The judge won’t rule until at least April." (https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/07/dakota-access-pipeline-court-battle-standing-rock-oil). Given the fact that the Judge has denied all of the tribes arguments up to now, its unlikely that he will overturn the federal permission in his future ruling.
Judge has ruled against tribes' legal challenge
I expect there will be resistance to slow it down.

Only tangentially related, but interesting to see how this case unfolds this week Coalition calls for charges to be dropped against Standing Rock journalists
https://cpj.org/2017/03/coalition-calls-for-charges-to-be-dropped-against-.php Had never heard of Unicorn Riot, must improve research
Based on news reports that is will be completed and operating in weeks.
Legal challenge seems unlikely to succeed

Further increasing forecast likelihood. Certain current legal efforts (i.e., to 'immediately' halt construction/implementation) seem fairly desperate/unlikely. Continuing to monitor. http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/judge-hear-arguments-dakota-access-oil-pipeline-work-45794754 http://nypost.com/2017/02/24/dakota-access-pipeline-could-be-carrying-oil-in-weeks/

Given the information available, I think it is highly unlikely that the DAPL will be stopped by legal processes and will, therefore, be transporting oil by January 2018. A hearing by Judge Boasberg is scheduled for today where he will listen to the argument put across by the Cheyenne River Tribe “about the religious harm arising from the mere siting of the pipeline under the tribes sacred waters” according to the tribes attorney Ducheneaux. 
However, both the Army Corps and ETP argue that “their religion argument is new…and the delay in raising it, is a reason for Boasberg to reject the argument” 
The Corps attorney, Erica Zilioli said “the governments permission for the company to lay pipe under the lake does not substantially burden the exercise of the tribes religious beliefs”. 
ETP’s attorney, William Scherman, is also arguing: “the tribes claim is suspect based on other man-made infrastructure under the lake”
 (https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/judge-to-hear-arguments-on-dakota-access-oil-pipeline-work/2017/02/28/8806165c-fd7d-11e6-9b78-824ccab94435_story.html?utm_term=.132bcb7b3a1b)   The man-made infrastructure that the attorney is referring to is stated in the Final Environmental Assessment: “The proposed pipeline would be routed to parallel existing linear infrastructure (an overhead power line and a buried gas transmission pipeline) across Lake Oahe in the same area” - Section 3.6.1 EA (http://www.nwo.usace.army.mil/Missions/Civil-Works/Planning/Project-Reports/Article/633496/dakota-access-pipeline-environmental-assessment/). A gas transmission pipeline carries the same rules and regulations as oil pipelines, provided by the PHMSA (phmsa.dot.gov). Granted the material transported by the DAPL and the gas pipeline are different, they are both considered hazardous so if there is already a pipeline in the same area as DAPL, then there is no justifiable way to legal overturn the construction.

Currently scheduled to begin by early April. Would only be prevented by sabotage or legal ruling. No suggestion or precedent for sabotage. I don't know how likely the legal action is to succeed, but nobody seems very helpful, so I'm making a wild guess of 90% Yes.

Protestors have been cleared from the area and the company is talking about having oil there in a couple weeks, probably faster than the courts can intervene: Given the interests on $3.8 Billion, it makes sense for them to race to complete the work; even if a court delays it they would want the pipe to be ready so they can get oil flowing as soon as they are allowed to. At this point sabotage might happen but is not likely to hold things up for months. Given the rush, there's a good chance there will be leaks and the companies probably don't care. https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2017/02/24/dakota-access-pipeline-could-be-operational-within-2-weeks.html

Jesuits disagree:
http://www.americamagazine.org/politics-society/2017/02/23/jesuits-call-dakota-pipeline-work-morally-unacceptable Haven't seen Silence yet, but Pope Francis holds greater weight than ever IMO

With the camp being removed, as long as there are no further hurdles the pipeline may be complete in a little as 1 month. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/22/us/a-deadline-looms-for-dakota-protesters-to-leave-campsite.html

As noted elsewhere, ETP reportedly "...estimates and targets that the pipeline will be complete and ready to flow oil anywhere between the week of March 6, 2017, and April 1, 2017."   ..Monitoring related developments in the days ahead including sched. 2/27/16 hearing with federal judge.. http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/dakota-pipeline-builder-oil-flow-weeks/story?id=45649701 http://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2017-02-22/showdown-looms-for-protesters-near-site-of-dakota-access-pipeline

Updating based on 
1) more aggressive company estimate.
http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/dakota-pipeline-builder-oil-flow-weeks/story?id=45649701 2) protesters leaving at the behest of Standing Rock Sioux Tribe.
https://www.mprnews.org/story/2017/01/21/standing-rock-tribe-asks-protesters-to-leave
It will be done within weeks. Oil will start flowing as soon as possible. ETP would not give up a chance to profit.

Given the current situation with protests and legal action taken by the tribe I would not put my forecast up to 100%, but I would say its pretty much a done deal that the pipeline will be operational this year.  It’s clear from the articles that give the sides of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe and ETP that lack of communication is what is driving the protests. The tribe wants to know the details for the pipeline which ETP is reluctant to give. “To be clear, the tribe does not oppose economic development, energy independence or protecting our national security,” Harrison said. “What we oppose is development that is undertaken without our consent and in such a way that it is our community, our people, our cultural sites and our natural resources that are put at the most risk, and when we are the ones who will pay the cost when something goes wrong.” (http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/dakota-access-pipeline-energy-transfer-partners-executive-vice-president-joey-mahmoud-compares-a7584841.html)  Judge Boasberg refused to stop construction in a ruling on February 13th - there is another hearing scheduled for February 27th. “US District Judge James Boasberg ruled that as long as oil isn’t flowing through the pipeline, there is no imminent harm to the Standing Rock Sioux and Cheyenne River tribes, which are suing to stop the project”. From the wording of this ruling it’s possible that there will be delays in the safety inspection phase, as he’s stating “as long as oil isn’t flowing”. It’s possible that any future rulings will just state that the rules of the PIPES act of 2016 must be met (https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/senate-bill/2276). It includes improved safety regulations, as it is updated from the PIPES Act of 2011, and requires the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) to update safety regulations, increase transparency and embrace emerging technologies.   For the people of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe the pipeline continuing does not mean they have lost their fight, instead they could turn their attention to the PIPES Act of 2016, which is only authorised until 2019, on how to improve regulations that will better protect their water.

As dawn breaks over an encampment that was once home to thousands of people protesting the Dakota Access oil pipeline, a few hundred holdouts rise for another day of resistance. They aren’t deterred by the threat of flooding, nor by declarations from state and federal authorities that they must leave by Wednesday or face possible arrest. They’re determined to remain and fight a pipeline they maintain threatens the very sanctity of the land.

Dakota Access pipeline constructions resume as Native American activists vow to fight on

https://www.ncronline.org/blogs/eco-catholic/standing-rock-sioux-vow-challenge-pipeline-court

"Feb. 9, 2017  A double-back decision by the Army to approve a final, critical permit for the Dakota Access Pipeline, while bypassing an environmental review, has led the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe and its allies to double down in their near-yearlong opposition to the contentious project they maintain endangers tribal water and sacred lands.
. . . 
"The Missouri River crossing is the last major piece of the 1,172-mile pipeline to be constructed.   Energy Transfer Partners officially received the easement the evening of Feb. 8. A spokeswoman told The Associated Press that construction would resume immediately. The company said it would be operational within months.
. . . 
"The order said it was complying with Trump's Jan. 24 memorandum that instructed the Army to expedite approval of Dakota Access "to the extent permitted by law," and consider withdrawing a prior directive for an environmental impact statement on the project, which the order also did. The environmental impact statement was requested by the Army in December, and was to include an examination of alternate routes and the risk of oil spills.
. . . 
'In the statement Feb. 7, the tribe vowed to challenge the order in court and continue to push for the completion of the environmental impact statement. . . . The tribe added that if the pipeline is completed, it will seek to shut operations down.
. . . 
" . . . the Native Nations March and will call on their representatives in Congress to support a letter sent the evening of Feb. 7 from Democratic members of the Senate and House natural resources committees that calls on the president "to immediately reverse this decision and follow the appropriate procedures required for tribal consultation, environmental law, and due process."
. . . 
"To abandon the [environmental impact statement] would amount to a wholly unexplained and arbitrary change based on the President's personal views and, potentially, personal investments. We stand ready to fight this battle against corporate interest superseding government procedure and the health and wellbeing of millions of Americans," the tribe said in a statement.
. . . 
Trump has promised to cut back environmental regulations that he said harms businesses, and to expedite the environmental review process.
~~~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I note the lack of specifics in the statements made by those opposed to this pipeline and that they are already talking about what they'll do if it is completed.
Slight upgrade from 60 to given dramatic consensus shift.
Beginning to look very likely now. Last statement says oil will be moved within 3 mths. Sabotage??

Construction resumes on Dakota pipeline despite tribe's challenge The company building an oil pipeline that has fueled sustained public protests said on Thursday it has started drilling under a North Dakota lake despite a last-ditch legal challenge from a Native American tribe leading the opposition. Energy Transfer Partners LP (ETP.N) is building the $3.8 billion Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) to move crude from the Northern Plains to the Midwest and then on to the Gulf of Mexico, now saying it could be operational by early May.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-north-dakota-pipeline-idUSKBN15O1Z3

On Tuesday, the Army changed course, informing Congress that it will grant permission for an easement — a special permit allowing a company to cross private or federal land — and complete the project, without finishing the environmental review.

Leaving a modest degree of uncertainty in forecast for now, about potential effectiveness of (ongoing) opposition to DAPL.  ..Presently appears difficult to stop pipeline completion/startup before the question's close date. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/drilling-resumes-on-the-dakota-access-pipeline/ http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/08/standing-rock-protesters-vow-mass-resistance-to-dakota-access.html
"Could be transporting oil within three months"

North Dakota tribe says running out of options to stop pipeline The leader of a Native American tribe attempting to block the Dakota Access oil pipeline said on Wednesday the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe may have exhausted legal options to stop the project after the company building it won federal permission to tunnel under the Missouri River. Legal experts agreed the tribe faces long odds in convincing any court to halt the $3.8 billion project led by Energy Transfer Partners LP, which could now begin operation as soon as June. 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-north-dakota-pipeline-idUSKBN15N2HP

The projected time to complete that section of pipeline is 100 days.  Even with weather delays, the construction may be completed before the end of April. Section 8.5 Winter Construction
Inclement weather such as snow fall or sub-freezing temperatures during the construction period has the potential to impact construction activities.  Pipeline construction typically can take place during difficult weather conditions, although construction progress may be slowed.   Section 8.10 Wet Weather Shutdown and Rutting
During construction, certain activities may be suspended in wet soil conditions, based on consideration of certain factors. Also, consultations appear complete according to the decision document. Environmental Assessment:  Dakota Access Pipeline Project, crossing of flowage easements and federal lands
http://cdm16021.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p16021coll7/id/2801 If the Dakota Access Pipeline is successfully completed and begins operating, the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe said it will “seek to shut the pipeline operations down.” 
Native Nations March on Washington is scheduled for March 10.  Will Congress get involved?
Source:  http://abcnews.go.com/US/standing-rock-sioux-tribe-vows-challenge-latest-army/story?id=45345993

1) The easement has been lifted and if construction could start today the company expects they would be done by June 1.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-administration-gives-final-approval-for-dakota-access-pipeline-1486500445 2) There have been studies done on environmental impact and with regard to archaeological findings.  It is unclear what additional studies would provide.  That is, it does not appear that the publicly stated reasons for the protest are true.  There may be different, valid reasons, but I did not find them in 5 minutes of looking.  I believe this makes it harder to scale protests and receive large donations. 3) It averages 3 degrees F in Feb at the location of the protests.  Difficult conditions to be out in.
https://www.wunderground.com/history/airport/K7L2/2017/2/8/MonthlyHistory.html?req_city=Standing%20Rock&req_state=ND&reqdb.zip=58538&reqdb.magic=3&reqdb.wmo=99999 Leaving 15% chance because the local police force has already let the federal government know it doubts its ability to remove protesters and protect construction workers. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2017/02/08/sheriffs-ask-trump-for-federal-help-with-dakota-access-pipeline-protesters/?utm_term=.fc96d9bbc90c  If construction is delayed until weather warms up in May I will lower the probability as I think there will be a larger set of people willing to protest throughout the summer and there are legal difficulties removing people from the tribe's land.

Pipeline co. and others have estimated only a few months (..roughly two to three-plus, I've read) to "finish the project", once construction is restarted.  http://www.dailynews.com/business/20170208/army-close-to-oking-finish-of-dakota-access-oil-pipeline https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/02/07/trump-administration-to-approve-final-permit-for-dakota-access-pipeline/?utm_term=.a825510f14f6

Recent approval of project and prospect for oil to start flowing by June.  Always a risk that additional litigation could tie this up in court, but since right of way isn't on Indian Affairs / reservation land, hard to see that happening.

In a court filing on Tuesday, the Army said that it would allow the final section of the line to tunnel under North Dakota's Lake Oahe, part of the Missouri River system. This could enable the $3.8 billion pipeline to begin operation as soon as June. 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-north-dakota-pipeline-idUSKBN15M2DU?il=0

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-north-dakota-pipeline-idUSKBN15M2DU "The U.S. Army will grant the final permit for the controversial Dakota Access oil pipeline after an order from President Donald Trump to expedite the project despite opposition from Native American tribes and climate activists.......Any legal challenge is likely to be a difficult one for pipeline opponents as presidential authority to grant such permits is generally accepted in the courts."
Nudging my forecast up, on news the ACE has given their green light. I'm now curious about the likelihood of delays due to court action.

Upping my prediction. Army Corps just cut short public comment period by two weeks to expedite approval as directed by Trump. Given all the other controversies that Trump has wrought on the US, I believe public uproar over pipeline construction will be too fragmented to significantly delay its construction. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/07/513951600/army-approves-dakota-access-pipeline-route-paving-way-for-the-projects-completio

Energy Transfer to Get Dakota Access Pipeline Approval From U.S. The controversial Dakota Access pipeline is set to win the final go-ahead for completion after President Donald Trump asked for a speedy approval. The U.S. Army said it will grant Energy Transfer Partners LP the easement it needs to finish the line that will ship almost half a million barrels of crude a day from North Dakota’s shale fields to refineries across the Midwest and on to the Gulf Coast. The approval of the easement the company needs to complete work follows Trump’s memorandum that advised expediting review of the project. Trump took office promising to favor oil and natural gas developments as well as support new infrastructure, such as reviving TransCanada Corp.’s Keystone XL pipeline.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-07/u-s-army-corps-to-grant-dakota-access-oil-pipeline-easement
Army Corps of Engineers announced it would approve today.

I think now it is highly likely that the DAPL will be transporting by January 2018.  The US government is taking steps to clear the protesters; ‘Federal government announced on Friday that is was dispatching Bureau of Indian Affairs agents to clear protesters.’ (washingtonpost.com). The US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) has given protesters until the 22nd February to leave the site. They say this is due to high-risk of flooding (nbcnews.com) but could also be in anticipation of construction. The DAPL is not far from completion so remaining construction would not take long. According to Phillips 66 the pipeline is more than 95% complete (yahoo.com) and according to the Presidential Memorandum (PM) its is 90% complete. The Presidential Memorandum regarding construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline states: “Consider, to the extent permitted by law and as warranted, prior reviews and determinations, including the Environmental Assessment issued in July 2016 for the DAPL to, as satisfying all applicable requirements of the National Environmental Protection Act, as amended 42 U.S.C 4321 et seq., and any other provisions of law that requires executive agency consultation or review..” 
(https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/01/24/presidential-memorandum-regarding-construction-dakota-access-pipeline)  The USACE environmental assessment which the PM is referring to found ‘no significant impact’ (http://www.nwo.usace.army.mil/Missions/Civil-Works/Planning/Project-Reports/Article/633496/dakota-access-pipeline-environmental-assessment/) . This is called a FONSI which means there is no significant impact to the quality of the environment, therefore, this does not stand in the way for an easement to be granted - as the argument in this case is the potential pollution of waters.
Trump is 100% committed to infrastructure building especially pipelines.

Dakota Access Pipeline May Not Be Operational Until Second Quarter of 2017
by Meenal Vamburkar  and Sheela Tobben
3 February 2017, 11:35 GMT-5 The $3.8 billion Dakota Access crude oil pipeline may start operating June 1, assuming no new obstacles prevent it, according to a person familiar with the matter. Energy Transfer Partners LP, the developer of the pipeline, will begin filling it with oil around Feb. 15, barring complaints or legal action to stop it, said the person, who asked not to be identified because the plan isn’t public. This single environment issue will become a symbol and cause that will galvanize and unify many diverse environmental and social justice groups, the pipeline issue will be tied in knots a year from now.  Millions of dollars will be donated to these groups, which will include environmental, tribal, and social justice law firms.  This has already happened in history.  Interior Secretary James Watt, in the Reagan administration, decided to open up the west for mining, logging, and drilling.  The blowback was nationwide, and a little hippy organization in San Francisco called the Sierra Club was launched.  James Watt was called "the Fort Knox of environmental fundraising."  My sense is that this pipeline effort is an overreach in an administration that has set itself up for many other fights.  Don't forget that many Albertans are against tar sands development too because of ecological damage and substantial greenhouse gas emissions. Now look at this economically, it is very costly to derive petroleum from tar sands.  The reasons they weren't developed decades ago was because the price of oil was too low.  Looking ahead to 2018, the price of oil is forecast to be stable, even flat.  The marginal economic returns may not be worth the fight either.

I'm surprised the commander in chief may not have the authority to command/order the Army Corps of Engineers, which was (I thought) the hold-up on this project, but that appears to be the case:  Washington Post:
It remained unclear how Trump’s order would expedite those environmental reviews. Many are statutory and the legislation that created them cannot be swept aside by an executive order...Trump’s [executive] order on the Dakota Access pipeline ...directs the Army Corps of Engineers to “review and approve in an expedited manner, to the extent permitted by law.” Wikipedia:
There is no constitutional provision nor statute that explicitly permits executive orders. The term executive power in Article II, Section 1, Clause 1 of the Constitution refers to the office of President as the executive. They are instructed therein by the declaration "take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed" made in Article II, Section 3, Clause 5 or face impeachment. Most executive orders use these Constitutional reasonings as the authorization allowing for their issuance to be justified as part of the President's sworn duties,[2] the intent being to help direct officers of the U.S. Executive carry out their delegated duties as well as the normal operations of the federal government: the consequence of failing to comply possibly being removal from office.[3]

The Army Corps of Engineers have submitted a Notice of Intent to start the EIS - as many forecasters have mentioned below - the period of this process could vary seeing as the Army Corps of Engineers had already done an EA (www.army.mil) which generally speeds up the time taken for an EIS to be completed (Citizens Guide to NEPA)  If I’m understanding how the NEPA process works correctly, then there might be subtle signs that Trump has started to make changes to environmental legislation already:  NEPA is a national policy that is achieved through EA’s and EIS’s. There are 3 federal agencies that have responsibilities for NEPA. The primary responsibility is held by the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) - a division of the Executive Office of the President.  The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) reviews EIS’s issued by federal agencies - in this case it will review the EIS the Corps of Engineers submits. The 3rd agency is the US Institute for Environmental Conflict and Resolution - this is a neutral party that attempts to solve disputes between agencies.  The EPA is crucial in other agencies NEPA processes as it is responsible for reviewing and commenting on the adequacy of analysis and the impact to the environment. Also has a system that summarises its recommendations to the lead agency (in the case of DAPL: US Army Corps of Engineers). EPA can decide if the action the lead agency has taken is environmental un/satisfactory. President Trump’s nominee to head the EPA is Attorney General Scott Pruitt has spent much of his career suing the EPA to roll back protection of the nations air and water (nytimes.com) and is also sponsored by fossil fuel companies. His confirmation vote is expected soon.  When the EPA determines the action is environmentally unsatisfactory, it is referred to the CEQ. Since President Trump’s inauguration, there is no longer a CEQ website nor has there been any mention of a new chair of the CEQ (CEQ chairmans are appointed by the President and confirmed by the senate).  Having Pruitt as the possible head of EPA, no mention yet of a new chair of the CEQ and the nominee for Energy Secretary Rick Perry (who wanted to scrap the department of energy (guardian.com)) - this EIS could eventually be determined as irrelevant under new legislation or rushed through.
New environmental assessments by Federal agencies will cause a substantial time lag before any decision(s) can be made with respect to opening the pipeline.

Still unlikely but trending toward even chance.  I've been reading Standing Rock Sioux Tribe et al. v. USACE (http://earthjustice.org/sites/default/files/files/order-denying-PI.pdf). There's a lot of acronyms such as NWP 12, PCN, and GC.  NWP refers to the Nationwide Permit which is a general permit that authorizes "the construction, maintenance, repair, and removal" of pipelines throughout the nation, where the activity will affect no more than a half-acre of regulated waters at any single water crossing.  A general permit tends to streamline the planning and construction process.  However, actions under the general permit must also comply with General Conditions.   The GCs may require that a particular covered action be subject to a PCN before work begins.  A PCN is a pre-construction notice and verification.  Of particular relevance is GC 20 which mandates a PCN for any permitted activity that "may have the potential to cause effects to any historic properties...including previously unidentified properties" of cultural or religious importance to the tribe.  I would contend that the concept of sacredness is largely foreign to many people who are not steeped in tribal tradition and culture.  In that sense, it is too easy to dismiss as unimportant.  But that aspect itself can be the crux of the government-to-government consultation. The case background goes on to state that a district engineer can also impose Regional Conditions where the district engineer deems the GC insufficient to protect tribal interests.  That’s about where I stopped in my reading. You know, I gotta say there’s an all too easy tendency to gravitate towards one side or the other based on one’s beliefs about the world and how it operates.  And, those beliefs may be contrary to the evidence at hand.

Decreased from previous forecast:
There are currently two court cases with DAPL: One filed by the ETP asking US District Judge James Boasberg to “declare it has legal right to lay the pipe under Lake Oahe”, as they've argued the Army Corps of Engineers gave permission in July 2016 through a permit granted under the federal Rivers and Harbours Act. The Corps said “ETP must satisfy the provisions of the federal Mineral Leasing Act which include an approval of an easement to work on federal land and the notification of Congress” (nytimes.com) - neither have been done.
The second case was filed by the tribes to challenge the federal permits for the pipeline at more than 200 water crossings. 
Judge Boasberg has asked for “the government to promptly notify the court should it change its position regarding the easement” (nytimes.com). The fact that Judge Boasberg has said this, indicates that it is possible for President-elect Trump to overturn the easement once he takes office. This delay is proving expensive for ETP, according to the papers they filed to the court, costing $4.5 million a month. DNB (largest bank in Norway) sold its assets in DAPL back in November, Odin Fund Management also sold $23.8 million worth of shares in the companies behind the pipeline and Nordea (Swedish bank) has said it would not back the pipeline if “the corporation violated the demands of the Standing Rock tribe”. (theguardian.com). It’s possible that the longer the DAPL is delayed, the more likely it is that companies with shares in the pipeline will start pulling out - due to lack of economic benefit.  According to the article in the NY times; construction has stopped while the court cases are ongoing thus extending the delay. It seems right now the prospect of the pipeline transporting oil before January 2018 is diminishing .

Dropping my forecast based on the history of relations between the Great Sioux Nation and the US government, with reference in particular to the Act of February 28, 1877.  SCOTUS concluded that "A more ripe and rank case of dishonorable dealings will never, in all probability, be found in our history." [United States v. Sioux Nation of Indians, 448 U.S. 371, 388 (1980) https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/448/371/] So now we have a situation where the pipeline was rerouted from its original location near Bismarck to its current location outside of the Standing Rock Reservation but sufficiently close enough to potentially impact tribal natural resources.  The Sioux Nation claim there has been insufficient government-to-government consultation.  Any action that invokes federal government involvement such as a permit issuance requires adherence to federal law which includes, e.g., Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act. Impossible?  No.  Unlikely?  Yes.

The US Army Corps released a statement on the 4th December 2016, stating that “additional analysis, more rigorous exploration and evaluation of reasonable siting alternatives, and greater public and tribal participation and comments” are needed in order for a decision on whether to authorise the crossing at Lake Oahe. (army.mil - Memorandum for commander, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers). This will be in the form of an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS - part of NEPA). 
Despite what was reported when this publication was released - this has not blocked the Dakota Access Pipeline from going ahead but has delayed it for the period that the EIS will take place.  
A research article published by Cambridge University in 2008 on how long it takes to prepare an EIS, stated that the time period varied from 53 days to 18.4 years (cambridge.org).  On December 1st 2016 Trump gave his support for the completion of the Dakota Access pipeline. On donaldjtrump.com ‘An American First Energy Plan’ he pledges to open onshore and offshore leasing on federal lands, eliminate moratorium on coal leasing and open shale energy deposits. It is public knowledge that Trump has stakes in Energy Transfer Partners (the company constructing the Dakota Access Pipeline) and Phillips 66 (who have a share in the Dakota Access Pipeline), which can be considered conflict of interest. In a statement released by his transition team “Trumps support of the pipeline has nothing to do with his personal investments and everything to do with promoting policies that benefit all Americans” (reuters.com). The new Administration could rush the process considering the Energy Secretary sits on the ETP board, the Head of the EPA is an oil mogul and the CEQ (which overseas federal agency implementation of EIS’s) are advisors to the President. However there is a procedure to follow, which involves the public - given the volume of people who have protested, there will be a large public involvement which could prolong the process if done properly.
The delays are political rather than environmental.  Whether they will be solved within a year, to allow the remaining portion of the pipeline to be built, is still uncertain.
